title: Dunning Springs Trail & Connector
text: Cash and I explored Dunning Springs Park in Decorah on 27-Jan-23. The trail to the springs is easy (and paved). The springs emanate from a limestone bluff and immediately cascade over a beautiful falls. You can walk right up to the falls or see them from above, along with the opening in the bluff, via wooded steps and an observation platform. There is also a steeply-ascending trail, the Dunning Springs Connector, that connects this area to the broader set of trails behind the Decorah Ice Cave.

title: Echo Valley Enviromental Nature Trail
text: Cash and I walked the Echo Valley Environmental Nature Trail near Echo Valley State Park just outside of West Union once in Summer (3-Jul) 2022 and again in Winter (25-Jan) 2023. The trail starts in Echo Valley State Park and follow Otter Creek for approximately 1.5 miles. It is an easy flat trail on an old railroad (or road). The scenery was beautiful, especially in the winter. Details are below.

title: Derek H. Ogle
text:
Iowa Hiking





I was born and raised in Iowa. When I return home now to see family, we try to explore some of the beautiful areas in Northeast (and some in East) Iowa. Below are some of our hikes.


Specific Hikes
Below are some specific hikes that we found interesting.

Echo Valley Environmental Nature Trail - West Union
Pulpit Rock - Decorah
Dunning Springs Park - Decorah
Backbone SP North Gate Rd - Dundee
Pony Hollow Trail I - Elkader

title: Derek H. Ogle
text:
Iron River Area Hiking





For exercise and for getting to know the area in which I have lived for the last three decades, Cash and I have been walking many of the roads and back-country trails in the Iron River WI area. Below are the places we have walked thusfar. Some specific walks are highlighted in the next section.












Interactions with Map




Red is highway, Blue is paved road, Orange is gravel road, Yellow is offroad (ATV but possible 4WD vehicle), Green is trail (hiking but some ATV), and Brown is designated ATV/Snowmobile (only) trail.
Hover on track to see track abbreviation.
Click on track to get track information.
Use +/- in upper-left to zoom.
Use object in upper-right to change base map type.
Use object in lower-left to make measurements on map.



 


Specific Hikes
Below are some specific hikes that we found interesting.

Camp Nine Research Area East

title: Blue Mesa Trail
text: On February 21, 2023 Kim and I visited Petrified Forest National Park on our way to Arizona. After the Puerco Pueblo Trail we stopped at the Blue Mesa Trail. The landforms here were simply amazing … the pictures don’t do them justice. Our next stop was the Crystal Forest Trail.

While we saw some petrified wood at the Blue Mesa Trail, this was the first trail with lots of wood. And the wood here was amazing … see the pictures below. Our next stop was the Long Logs and Agate House Trails.

title: Long Logs and Agate House Trails
text: On February 21, 2023 Kim and I visited Petrified Forest National Park on our way to Arizona. After the Crystal Forest Trail we stopped at the Long Logs and Agate House Trails. The first part of the Long Logs Trail was on an old road. We turned off this to follow the Agate House Trail to the Agate house, which was both interesting and beautiful (see the pictures below). The rest of the Long Logs trail was neat, with many large petrified wood specimens.

title: Painted Desert Rim Trail
text: On February 21, 2023 Kim and I visited Petrified Forest National Park on our way to Arizona. After a quick stop at the visitor center we embarked on the short Painted Desert Rim Trail. The panoramic views were impressive and it was fun to see the Painted Desert Inn. Our next stop was the Puerco Pueblo Trail.

title: Picacho Peak, Santa Fe, NM
text: On February 19, 2023 Kim and I hiked to Picacho Peak in Dale Ball North trail system in Santa Fe. The trail was well-marked and easy to follow, but snowy so we appreciated our YakTraks. The views were stunning which made for an awesome little hike that fit our time in Santa Fe well. [It was also crazy for us flat-landers to be above 8000 feet!!]

title: Piedra Marcadas Trail
text: On February 20, 2023 Kim and I also walked the Piedra Marcadas (North Rim and main) trail in Petroglyph National Monument just outside Albuquerque. The North Rim trail is basically a walk through a mesa, but once your drop down onto the main trail the ridge is covered with numerous petroglyphs. The trail starts behind a gas station (or was it a Wallgreens) so I did not have high hopes, but both parts of the trail were interesting, with the petroglyphs being especially neat.

title: Sandia Peak Aerial Tramway
text: On February 20, 2023 Kim and I took the Sandia Peak tram to Sandia Peak. While this was not technically a “hike” I did map it to see that we climbed nearly 3800 feet to ~10300 feet. The change in temperature from the bottom to the top was striking, but the views from the tram and the peak were spectacular. At the top we hiked for a bit on the South Crest Trail.

title: South Crest Trail, Sandia Peak
text: On February 20, 2023 Kim and I hiked part of the South Crest Trail on Sandia Peak after taking the Sandia Peak Aerial Tram up the mountain. There was a lot of snow and we were not fully prepared for the much colder temperatures so we did not hike the complete trail. However, the portion that we did was beautiful and providing some amazing view “over the edge.”

title: Black Top Mesa from First Water TH
text: On March 9, 2022 Kim and I hiked to Black Top Mesa from the First Water trailhead via Dutchman’s and Bull Pass trails. This was a long walk for us (~12.5 mi) but offered stunning views of Weaver’s Needle from the north, which we had not seen before. The climb up to the top was steep but the trail was fairly easy to navigate. We returned to the trailhead via the Black Mesa and Second Water trails. There were many more cacti no the trail back. Fun hike. Details are below.

title: Hackberry Springs Loop
text: On February 24, 2023 Kim and I hiked the Hackberry Springs loop (from the First Water TH) on a beautiful sunny day. This loop was one of the first hikes we did five or so years ago. At that time we had very little experience and were navigating with a small map in a dated book. We completed the hike then but it was much more comfortable this time as we had more experience hiking in the desert and were using our Avenza. This is quite a beautiful trail, especially on the way down to and out of Hackberry Springs. My favorite part is the high bluffs along the stream.

title: Peralta to Canyon Lake Marina
text: On February 23, 2023 Kim and I embarked on our first walk-through hike in the Superstition Mountains. Our “support team” dropped us off at the Peralta TH about 7am when it was 45oF. It was a pretty easy hike to Fremont Saddle, which we had done before. We then dropped over the saddle and continued on the Peralta Trail past the Needle to the Boulder Canyon Trail. It was neat to be so close to the Needle during this part of the trail. The Boulder Canyon Trail proved to be a bit challenging because the stream was fairly full of water and we had to cross it 25 times. Most crossings were pretty straight-forward, but there were several where we had to search up or downstream to find rocks close enough for both of us to cross. After our final crossing we climbed pretty steeply out of the canyon to get our first view of Canyon Lake and an awesome view back to the south of the terrain we had covered. A downhill hike to Canyon Lake Marina where our “support team” picked us up. We then went to Tortilla Flats for a beer and burger! My favorite part of this trail was seeing Weaver’s Needle from many different perspectives. All-in-all a fun trail that was 14.8 miles long and took us about 8.5 hours to complete.

title: Robber’s Roost Loop
text: On February 25, 2023 I hiked to Robber’s Roost via the Carney Springs Trail (starting at the Lost Goldmine East TH) and returning via the Cave Trail. The climb up the Carney Springs Canyon got my heart pumping (~1300 feet elevation gain in a little over a mile). Finding the path into Robber’s Roost was difficult, but as I got closer I could hear voices and when I met the hikers outside of the Roost they offered to show me the “secret” passage into it (Thanks, Juan). It was amazing to stand in the Roost and the views out the fractures in the wall were beautiful. I returned through Fremont Saddle (a little less than a mile from the Roost) and down the Cave Trail, which had some navigational challenges as it did last year (I did not miss Geronimo’s Cave this year, though!). This was a challenging (the climb and some route-finding), but beautiful (views from on top, the Roost) hike that I will do again (with Kim).

title: Derek H. Ogle
text: My wife Kim and I particularly like to travel and take walks with our sheltie Cash (as we did with Jem and Jordan). I also tend to our Oulu property, fish, boat, cross-country ski, snowshoe, attend live music, and smoke fish and meat. I also make occasional TV appearances, the most famous of these is my appearance on Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives.

title: Derek H. Ogle
text:
Kim and I enjoy all kinds of live music, particularly at Big Top Chautauqua, which is only an hour from home. I primarily listen to blues-rock (think SRV, KWS, etc) and outlaw country (Waylon, Willie, etc.) but we have been know to travel good distances to see Michael Franti, JJ Grey & Mofro, Ronnie Baker Brooks, and Corey Carlson.



Click the image above to see some of the musicians that we have met.

Jem
Jem graced our lives from April(ish) 2009 to almost August 2018. Many people knew Jem from seeing him around the Science Center during the school year. Jem was such a special dog … very smart, incredibly loyal, and always watching over and protecting us. While he was a little snooty and often turned up his nose at “strangers”, he also melted your heart if he decided to give you the time of day. Here is a short piece that I wrote about Jem a few years ago.
Jem was taken from us way too early, though we know he is now with his “grandpa owner” taking walks, sitting on the couch together, and scheming to get those chippies. RIP “poundy”, I wish we would have had more time together, you were such a special little guy!! We will see you again (Thanks Ronnie … beautiful song).














































































 


Jordan
Kim and I got Jordan soon in 1991, soon after we were married. “Jordo” enriched our lives until March 2006. We miss the walks and boat rides. RIP “Bordo Dog”!!!

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline II
text:
Introduction
In a previous post I introduced the Pike Chain of Lakes, explained temperature profile plots and the typical seasonality of temperature by depth data, and examined temperature by depth data that are publicly available through the Wisconsin DNR Citizen Lake Monitoring Network. Here I explore dissolved oxygen data from the same source.
 






Summary




Multiple dissolved oxygen profiles can be constructed for each year since 2012.
Dissolved oxygen profiles closely match the temperature profiles relative to the thermocline.
Dissolved oxygen values above the thermocline were nearly always above 6 mg/L, which is considered to be good oxygen levels for warmwater fishes.

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline II
text:
Temperature Oxygen Relationship & Seasonality
As noted in the previous post, deep lakes in our area develop a thermocline in the summer, with relatively warm water near the surface (to approximately 25-30 feet) and relatively cool water near the bottom of the lake, with a zone of rapidly decreasing temperature (the thermocline) in between. The colder deeper water is more dense then the warmer surface waters and the thermocline in between limits the ability of the water in these two zones to mix. Generally, all plant life and plant growth occurs in the warmer surface waters, thus, producing oxygen (in dissolved format) for this zone. In contrast, in the deeper zone, no new oxygen is being added and oxygen is being used by bacteria as organic matter is broken down. These processes result in a faily well oxygenated zone above the thermocline and an area of (sometimes extreme) oxygen depltion below the thermocline. The result is that the dissolved oxygen profile tends to be very similar to the temperatue profile (Figure 1).





Figure 1: Temperature and dissolved oxygen profile plots for August 1, 1991. The thin line at the top represents the water surface and the thicker line at the bottom represents the lake bottom.




 
The oxygen profile just described sets up quickly on our lakes following the spring turnover period. Our Eagle Lake data does not include samples from early enough in the year to show the vertical mixing throughout the water column. However, Figure 2 shows the general pattern described above for all sample dates, but also shows the general tend that dissolved oxygen in the upper layer is higher in the early and late samples as cooler water can hold more dissolved oxygen.





Figure 2: Dissolved oxygen profile plots for nine dates throughout the open-water season in 2020.

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline II
text:
Eagle Lake DO Profiles





Figure 3: Dissolved oxygen profiles separated by year (panels) and observation dates. Profile colors start with blue for early May transition through purple and pink to red for early July and then transition through orange and brown to green for late fall. The vertical dashed red line is at 6 mg/L.

title: Eagle Lake Ice-Out
text:
Comparison to Other Lakes
Lake Nebagamon is much larger (986 acres) but with a similar maximum depth (56 ft) as Eagle Lake that is approximately 20 miles nearly straight west of Eagle Lake. With the exception of a few notable years, the ice-out dates between these two lakes are quite similar. Lake Mendota is a very large (9781 acres) and deep (83 ft maximum) lake that is approximately 350 miles south of Eagle Lake. The ice-out dates for Mendota are always before those for Eagle Lake, but the very generally track together.





Figure 3: Eagle Lake ice out dates by year with other lakes shown for comparison.

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline
text:
Introduction
The Pike Chain of Lakes near Iron River, WI is a set of nine connected lakes, seven of which have relatively consistent water quality data. The Pike Chain is highly developed, has several public access locations, and is popular among anglers, boaters, snowmobilers, etc. year-round. Over the years, especially recently since Eurasian watermilfoil was introduced, volunteers have recorded various water quality parameters for the Pike Chain of Lakes. Below I show the record of temperature by depth recordings that are publicly available through the Wisconsin DNR Citizen Lake Monitoring Network.
 






Summary




Multiple temperature profiles can be constructed for each year since 2012.
The thermocline has begun to form by the earliest observations in May and is beginning to breakup in October (where those observations exist).
The top of the thermocline is generally between 15-20 feet deep in mid to late summer.
The bottom of the thermocline is generally betwen 25-30 feet deep in mid to late summer.

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline
text:
Temperature Profile Plot
A temperature profile plot shows the water temperature at various depths through the water column (Figure 1). Depth is shown with the water surface at the top and the lake bottom at the bottom of the left axis. Temperature increases from left to right on the bottom axis.





Figure 1: Temperature profile plot for August 1, 1991. The thin line at the top represents the water surface and the thicker line at the bottom represents the lake bottom.




Figure 1 illustrates a typical mid-summer profile where the temperature is fairly and consistently warm near the surface (75-80oF from 0 to 15 ft) declines quickly over a fairly narrow depth range (drops from 75oF to 50oF from 15 to 30 ft) and then stays fairly and consistently cool at greater depths.

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline
text:
Seasonal Changes in Temperature Profile
In winter (under the ice in northern Wisconsin) and at ice-out the water temperature will be a nearly constant 39oF from top to bottom (perhaps a little cooler at the ice-water interface). However, as spring progresses the surface water becomes warmer and moving into summer that warmer water will extend deeper into the lake. However, in most lakes in our area there will be a depth where the water temperature begins to decline dramatically over a fairly narrow depth range (see Figure 1). Eventually there will be a depth where the water temperatures stays fairly and constantly cold below that depth. The transition zone of water temperatures quickly declining from warmer surface to cooler below-surface water is called the thermocline. As fall approaches the process is reversed such that the surface water will cool (and, thus, sink) until the water temperature is again fairly constant throughout the water column.
On Eagle Lake we do not have water column temperature data very near the ice-out and ice-in dates. Thus, the seasonal phenomenon just described cannot be fully illustrated for Eagle Lake. However, Figure 2 shows the general trend of warmer surface water, the thermocline, and cooler water at deeper depths through the open-water months. The warming and then cooling of the surface water layer is also evident in Figure 2.





Figure 2: Temperature profile plots for six dates throughout the open-water season in 2018.




 
The dissolution of the thermocline in late fall was more evident in the data from 2020, where the temperature was almost constant throughout the water column on the last observation date of October 16 (Figure 3).





Figure 3: Temperature profile plots for nine dates throughout the open-water season in 2020.

title: Pike Chain of Lakes Secchi Depths
text:
Introduction
The Pike Chain of Lakes near Iron River, WI is a set of nine connected lakes (Figure 1). The Pike Chain is highly developed, has several public access locations, and is popular among anglers, boaters, snowmobilers, etc. year-round. Over the years, especially recently since Eurasian watermilfoil was introduced, volunteers have recorded various water quality parameters for the Pike Chain of lakes. Below I show the record of Secchi depth recordings that are publicly available through the Wisconsin DNR Citizen Lake Monitoring Network.





Figure 1: Satellite image of the nine lakes that form the Pike Chain of Lakes.




A Secchi disk is an 8-inch disk painted in quadrants with black and white that is lowered into a lake to assess water clarity. The depth at which the disk is no longer visible is called the Secchi depth and is a measure of water transparency; the deeper the depth the more transparent the water. Water transparency can be a surrogate for water quality (more transparent generally means higher water quality) and can be an indicator of human activity on and around the lake. See this and this for quick introductions to Secchi disks.
 






Summary




Data was inconsistently recorded across lakes.
Muskellunge Lake had the shallowest Secchi depth, whereas Lake Millicent and Hart Lake had the deepest (see Figure 2).
Average Secchi depth varied annually within each lake, with no clear trend of increasing or decreasing in most lakes (see Figure 3),

title: Derek H. Ogle
text:
I worked for Northland College as a fisheries and statistics professor for 26 years until 2022. I believe in Northland’s mission and core values surrounding the environment, sustainability, and social justice. I very much enjoyed helping students to reach their academic and career goals.
While at Northland (and both before and since) I had opportunities to pursue my own scholarly interests. Towards that end I authored a fisheries-related book, book chapter, and several journal articles, and developed software mostly related to fisheries analyses.
Though retired from that career I still, as part of the fishR core team, actively maintain the fishR webpage1 and several fisheries-related R packages.
My professional record is recorded on my CV and in the links above and below.

        





Footnotes


Resources for performing fisheries analyses in R.↩︎

title: Software
text:
FSA (Fisheries Stock Assessment): R functions to conduct typical introductory fisheries analyses. Example analyses that use FSA are in the Introductory Fisheries Analyses with R book.
FSAdata: A companion to FSA with data sets for use in common fisheries analyses.
RFishBC: Helps collect measurements from calcified structures and back-calculate estimated lengths at previous ages.







These packages are now maintained by the fishR-Core-Team, of which I am a member.

title: Software
text:
Unreleased R Packages

FSAWs: For constructing and validating standard weight (Ws) equations for fish.
NCStats: Helper functions for statistics courses at Northland College.







Other packages that are less well-developed or maintained are available on my Github page

pgirmess::kruskalmc(): A generic wrapper function for performing multiple comparisons for a Kruskal-Wallis test.
car::leveneTest(): A generic wrapper function for performing Levene’s homogeneity of variances test.
plotrix::plotH(): Construct histogram-like modifications of scatterplots.
